content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: harder than the average CoC for sure, but it is very nice and pretty challenging
(solved in 6 lines of python with iteration)

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: I really like the idea of this one, but while doing this, I realize that to decode it once is pretty enough of a competition for CoC, it's obviously doable within 5 minutes, but for certain languages, to make it recursive and to figure out how to make it work, it looks harder than expected and longer than estimated time. Also, in tihs conditions, it is not for Reverse mode imo.
Good job!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's a fun and simple puzzle that makes you think but can be readily solved once the basic concept is grasped.  Clear and well written description
Nice, especially the bit where a binary sequence can decode to another...

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Now it can be done within 5 minutes

Ok, additional i think it could be hard to figure out the errors in reverse (like Flaaamort said) so i will remove the errors, but i will add fast mode back again. This should be solvable within 5 min without the errors now.  :)

I love the idea of this puzzle, doing this in reverse might be very interesting, but then error handling is a bit too complex I think. Having to apply the conversion recursively seems like a hard enough challenge for Clash of Code in my opinion

I removed this task from fast mode, because to many ppl said, recursive binary to ascii conversion is to hard in 5 min. But i changed the discription a bit so that the task is more clear, maybe i could add fast mode back again after theese changes.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: I dont think everyone will be able to finish this in less than 5 minutes.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Also took me too long to solve. :(
Quite long challenge if you do it in c

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: I refuse this proposal because it took longer than 5 minutes to solve and don't think it would be good for the fastest mode.
Good CoC for fastest and shortest modes. Last tests seem hard for reverse mode.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice clash !

With the statement its easy and fun. Nice job.
Without it (reverse) I do not know how I would figure the error cases (I do not speak binary fluently, sorry :) )

I approve for Fastest and Shortest but not for reverse ^^

Hi. I could do it and if was fun. However the statement is not enough to understand the problem. We need to run all the examples to be sure we did fine and this is pure reverse engineering. 
As the statement is not enough, I will downvote it. I think it cannot be accepted as is. You have to fully rewrite it so that everything is fully understandable.

ok, i will give more infos to solve it, i though the in and output was clear enough, but ok, maybe i was to much thinking about reverse :)

edit: i changed the goal description, but i think now it's to easy

I agree with MrPapaya, I think two hints about the conditions of data corruption would be necessary to let coders complete this task under 5 minutes
As you require :
- recursive evaluation of binary ASCII
- throwing non 8-tuple messages (anywhere in the recursion process)
This seems quite difficult to handle with so few info about the data, particularly in reverse mode
Except for that I would upvote as the puzzle is great
Would be nice to have more clarity of what data is broken.
hopefully u had some fun with it :D

This was harder than I expected. I was doing it in reverse, without reading the statement. so i guess it's doable.

shitty ruby solution:
s=gets
f=->l{l.chars.each_slice(8).map{(_1*"").to_i(2).chr}*""}
s="ERROR" if s.size%8>0
(s=f[s];s="ERROR" if s=~/^[10]+$/&&s.size%8>0) while s=~/^[10]+$/
puts s
Even Fastest and Shortest are like Reverse
i changed the description a little bit, i think now it's easier to understand

Did you read this: https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/contribution-guidelines
"CoC statements should be self-sufficient."

In the case of your sample, we need the tests to understand the problem that you don't describe in details. Normally, the user should be able to understand the problem to solve just by reading the statement. Then the tests are here to help him debug his code, not to help him understand the problem to solve.
I don't really agree. Seeing the output, we will guess it's binary to ASCII conversion. Then with trial and errors we will make it work. Not sure the double encoding is suitable for reverse however?
Thanks for the hint.

Thank you for your feedback, but in my opinion, when you start with binary data and see binary data again after the decode in reverse mode, i think it is comprehensible what to do. maybe its a bit harder, but it's doable i think. Let's wait the shitstorm, which will rain on me :D

I can understand what you mean, but let's see how good this in coc goes. Maybe i will remove this task for reverse later when it's really to hard. I've played a lot of clashed and got some weird puzzles with about 10000 characters in the task description, i think this puzzle is a good one to have a smart puzzle where you need a bit more thinking of it to solve.

It's hard to respect all languages, when i think about ruby and shortcode, puzzles should also been balanced that the language itself given't you a handicap, but it's nearly impossible and we have to live with it.
Nice that you like it, i've got 3 lines in js :P

The main point was that it can be solved with iteration. The description says recursion is needed.
One other suggestion is that if you add an extra test which only decodes to a single letter that would probably help a lot of people, especially in reverse mode.

"The description says recursion is needed."
- it's still a recursive operation at this point where you have to decode the result multiple times, if you use an loop for this, it's in your choice, loops and recursive calls do the same job, maybe i can remove this info, that some people not get confused when they think they have to write an recursive function for this
"if you add an extra test which only decodes to a single letter that would probably help a lot of people"
- i will take a look for this, thanks

In my opinion, this CoC must be enhanced and polished to be usable.
Personally, I don't like it when I need the tests to understand the problem to be solved in a CoC. This is what the statement is here for.
This means I need to add a lot of prints and to play all the tests 1 by 1.
i changed the first text a little bit, i hope it's more clear now
